title-group.article-title: Material and structural response of polymer-matrix fibre-reinforced composites

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Aeronautics, South Kensington Campus, Imperial College London, London, UK
3DEMEGI, Faculdade de Engenharia, Universidade do Porto, Rua Dr. Roberto Frias, Porto, Portugal

author-notes.corresp: ST Pinho, Department of Aeronautics, South Kensington Campus, Imperial College London, London SW7 2AZ, UK Email: silvestre.pinho@imperial.ac.uk

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper presents a pressure-dependent three-dimensional constitutive law to predict failure for laminated composites. The nonlinear constitutive response in shear and in the transverse and through-the-thickness directions, which is measured experimentally, is incorporated directly into the model. In addition, secant stiffnesses are dependent on the state of hydrostatic pressure and on the general state of strain. The failure criteria distinguish between matrix failure, fibre kinking and fibre tensile failure. In-situ strengths are used for matrix failure. Propagation of failure takes into consideration the fracture energy associated with each failure mode and, for matrix failure, the accumulation of cracks in the plies. A detailed discussion is undertaken of the mismatch between the available experimental data and the physical properties required to characterise the constitutive response up to final failure. The model is employed to make blind predictions of the triaxial failure envelopes and stress–strain curves of all 12 test cases provided by the organisers of the second World-Wide Failure Exercise.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This paper describes the contribution of the authors to the second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II). The exercise aims at assessing the predictive capabilities of existing failure criteria and models for laminated polymeric-matrix fibre-reinforced composites consisting of unidirectional plies, and subjected to a three-dimensional (3D) stress state. While most previous publications in the area have focused on plane-stress, many applications of composite structures typically involve 3D stress states. The out-of-plane stress components can be due to the design of the component, e.g. ‘T’-joint, or to the application, e.g. hydrostatic pressure in marine or aircraft components.

The approach presented here follows previous work by the authors,1–4 and includes further developments. The previous failure criteria published by the authors were designated as LaRC02,5 LaRC036 and LaRC04,2 and the ones presented in this paper can thus be designated as LaRC05. The philosophy behind the approach is that failure models and resulting criteria ought to include as much as possible of the physics associated with the failure process at the micromechanical level, while still allowing for solutions to be computed for laminae and laminates.

The current knowledge of the physics of failure in composites is incomplete. In some cases, the limitations on the understanding of the failure process, together with the need to obtain a workable solution, require assumptions, approximations and heuristics. In other cases, the data required to fully characterise the plies is not available and has to be estimated. The comparisons with experimental results will ultimately establish whether the simplifications, assumptions and estimations are appropriate, or whether they need to be reassessed. Despite the current incomplete physical understanding of failure in composites, the physical basis for the models provides a solid foundation which not only allows for predicting the failure event but also the failure mode and the consequences of failure in terms of residual materials properties.

This paper starts by discussing the nonlinear material response of composites, which is assumed to result exclusively from the nonlinear response of the resin. The experimental findings show that the constitutive response of laminated composites is relatively complex, but the inclusion of this complexity in a model is required to obtain an accurate stress field for each ply of a laminate. In turn, an accurate stress field is essential to accurately predict failure of a laminate. Failure criteria are formulated at the ply level and can distinguish between matrix cracking, fibre kinking and fibre tensile failure. The present damage propagation model predicts the response of laminates from first ply failure until final laminate failure. In addition to any imperfections associated with the models presented, the ability of these models to predict the test cases of the WWFE-II depends on the exact definition of the problems to be simulated and on the knowledge of the relevant material properties. The factors affecting the accuracy of the models and respective predictions for each test case are presented.

sec.title: Nonlinear constitutive response of unidirectional composite plies
Nonlinear response of polymers
sec.p:
Most polymers used in engineering respond linearly for low applied strains, after which yielding with hardening occurs, as illustrated in Figure 1. While the exact hardening curve depends on the polymer, the response tends to be qualitatively similar for different data published in the literature.7–12 For shear and compressive loading, three different areas can be identified, Figure 1(a) and (b). In the first region, the polymer behaves linearly. In the second region, the entangled polymer chains straighten and move relative to each other, eventually breaking some cross-links in the process. In the third region, there is an added resistance to any further straightening, which might be caused by the cross links and entanglement of the polymer chains. For tensile loading, Figure 1(c), yielding is usually not as prominent because existing microcracks propagate and break the specimen before any substantial yielding takes place. Rabinowitz et al.13 and Schuecker et al.14 point out that there are two different mechanisms competing for failure: yielding and brittle fracture. For certain stress states, failure results from excessive yielding, while in others brittle fracture occurs prior to any significant yielding. Figure 1.
Typical response of a polymer; (a) three regions in a shear curve; (b) compressive loading and (c) brittle response in tension.

Under superimposed hydrostatic pressure, both the Young’s modulus and the shear modulus increase with pressure,12,15 see Figure 2(a). For most experimental data published, the dependence of initial (linear elastic) moduli with pressure can be approximated reasonably with a linear function, see e.g. Figure 2(b). However, many authors identify two separate regions with different slopes,13,15,17 with the kink between the regions related to the dependence of the glass transition temperature on pressure. The dependence of the elastic moduli on the hydrostatic pressure is probably related to the compressibility of the resin and the added resistance to deformation of the entangled polymer chains when hydrostatic pressure is superimposed. The linear dependence of the moduli with hydrostatic pressure can be predicted with good accuracy for a wide range of polymers15 using a model proposed by Birch.18 Birch’s model is simple and only requires the moduli at atmospheric pressure and the Poisson’s ratio of the polymer: (1)E=Eo+ηEpr with ηE=2(5-4ν)(1-ν),G=Go+ηGpr with ηG=3(3-4ν)2(1+ν), where E and G are the initial Young’s and shear moduli, respectively, Eo and Go are the Young’s and shear moduli (in the elastic region) at a reference pressure, respectively, pr is the pressure (relative to the pressure at which Eo and Go are measured) and ν is the Poisson’s ratio. Values of the slope parameters ηE and ηG measured experimentally for different polymer systems are shown in Table 1. Figure 2.
Effect of pressure on (a) the compressive response of a polymer, after reference [16], and (b) the initial shear modulus, after reference [11]. Table 1.
Pressure coefficients for several composites and resins
Reference Material ηE ηG ηL
[11] Carbon T300 epoxy PR319 60%
0.19–0.21 0.082
[17] E Glass–epoxy 15.1–17.1
0.08–0.19
[20] Glass–epoxy 60%
0.2
[21] Kevlar Epoxy 12.2
[15] Epoxy PR319
0.48 0.073
[17] Epoxy MY750/HY917/DY063 100:85:2 6.2
[22] CA 5.1
[22] PC 4.1
[15] PCTFE 3
[23] PE 4.1
[23] PI 3
[24] POM
0.07
[23] PP 4.1
[24] PP
0.21
[17] PTFE 3.3
[23] PVC 3.2

Figure 2(a) shows that, while the hydrostatic pressure results in an increased yield stress, the yield strain is not significantly affected. In fact, the boundaries between the three regions identified in Figure 1(a) and (b) are almost unaffected by the superimposed hydrostatic pressure. The effect of hydrostatic pressure is essentially to shift the curves up, while any horizontal shifting appears to be less significant. These observations suggest that the yielding in the resin is controlled by the state of deviatoric strain, rather than by the state of stress, which seems reasonable, as the yielding results from the relative movement of the entangled polymer chains.

sec.title: Nonlinear response of composites
sec.p:
For polymer-matrix fibre-reinforced composites, the nonlinear response of the matrix induces a nonlinear response of the composite. Experimental data for several composites15 show a pressure-dependence of the Young’s and shear moduli (see Figure 3), similar to the one observed in pure polymer. Therefore, the dependence of the moduli with pressure can be described using expressions analogous to those in equation (1). As with pure resin, the most significant effects of hydrostatic pressure appear to be to shift the stress vs. strain curves up, and to allow larger plastic deformation to occur before fracture. Any distortion or shifting in the strain axis appears to be much less significant. Just like for pure resin, these observations suggest that yielding is mainly controlled by the state of deviatoric strain rather than by the state of stress. Figure 3.
Effect of pressure on (a) the whole shear response of a composite, and (b) the initial shear modulus, after reference [12].

The slope coefficients ηE and ηG for the composite can either be measured experimentally or deduced from the slope coefficients for the polymer using a suitable micromechanical model. Hine et al.17 compared the two approaches for a glass/epoxy using Wilczynski’s model19 and obtained a good agreement. If the slope coefficients of the composite are obtained from the slope coefficients of the polymer, then those latter coefficients can be either measured experimentally or calculated using Birch’s model.18 Values of the slope parameters ηE and ηG measured experimentally for different composites are shown in Table 1.

Yielding and matrix cracking are two different mechanisms. While yielding is related to the deviatoric strain state in the matrix, matrix cracking is a fracture mechanics problem. The amount of yielding that can take place before fracture initiation depends on the load case and on the stacking sequence. For composites, unstable crack propagation can take place at early stages of deformation, due to existing microscopic defects in the composite. Therefore, the amount of yielding and the matrix-related strengths of the composite are very dependent on these initial defects, particularly when the state of stress includes no significant compression to close existing microcrack tips. This argument has two main implications. Firstly, because the magnitude of the initial defects depends on the type of specimen and stacking sequence, the amount of yielding before fracture also depends on the type of specimen and stacking sequence. This explains for instance why a ±45° ASTM D3518 standard specimen for the determination of shear properties25 exhibits more yielding than a V-notched rail shear specimen.26 While the small individual layer thickness in the ±45° specimen limits the maximum defect size, and the bounding layers restrict unstable crack propagation, the unidirectional rail shear specimen can accommodate large manufacturing defects, and the stacking sequence is such that cracks can propagate unstably throughout the thickness of the laminate. The second implication is that, under conditions that tend to close the initial microcracks, the amount of yielding before failure should increase. This explains why there is more yielding at higher hydrostatic pressures, as demonstrated in Figure 3(a). As a result, it appears clear that these two mechanisms – yielding and matrix cracking – have to be represented by two separate models. The model for the nonlinear constitutive response with yielding and that for the fracture of the matrix are presented below.

sec.title: Nonlinear constitutive model for unidirectional composite plies
Pressure dependence and yielding
sec.p: The strains ε in a composite ply are related to the stresses σ in the same ply through Hooke’s law for orthotropic materials (2){ɛ1ɛ2ɛ3γ12γ23γ31}=[1/E1-ν12/E1-ν13/E10001/E2-ν23/E20001/E30001/G1200sym.1/G2301/G31]{σ1σ2σ3τ12τ23τ31}, or, in short, (3)ɛ=Dσ.

Assuming transverse isotropy in equation (2), E3=E2, G13=G12, ν13=ν12 and G23=E22(1+ν23). To completely define the constitutive law, the dependence of five material properties with loading needs to be established: E1, E2, G12, ν12 and ν23. However, the variation of E1, ν12 and ν23 is less significant than the variation of E2 and G12. Therefore, only the dependence of E2 and G12 on the stress and strain state is considered here. By virtue of their dependence on E2 and G12 (due to the assumed transverse isotropy), the moduli E3, G13 and G23 also depend on the stress and strain states.

To represent the effect of pressure on the moduli detailed above, the following expressions for E2 and G12 are proposed: (4)E2=E2 o+ηEpG12=G12 o+ηGp, where E2 o and G12 o are the secant Young’s and shear moduli at atmospheric pressure, respectively, and ηE and ηG are slope coefficients for the transverse Young’s and shear moduli, respectively. Because the stress in the fibre direction is mainly supported by the fibres, the variable p, which corresponds to the hydrostatic pressure pr in equation (1), is redefined here as the transverse hydrostatic pressure (5)p=-σ2+σ32.

As discussed above, the secant Young’s and shear moduli for zero (or atmospheric) hydrostatic pressure, E2 o and G12 o, are functions of the strain state, since they are affected by yielding. Since the second invariant of the deviatoric strain tensor includes terms in ε1, which is considered here not to contribute significantly to yielding, a modified version of the invariant that excludes terms in ε1 is empirically chosen to define an equivalent strain (6)ɛeq=(ɛ2-ɛ3)2+γ12 2+γ23 2+γ31 2 such that, under monotonic loading, E2 o and G12 o are defined as: (7)E2 o=E2 o(ɛeq)G12 o=G12 o(ɛeq).

The nonlinear curves defined by equation (7) are determined experimentally under uniaxial loading conditions. The experimental curves are assumed to remain valid for all combinations of loading conditions when expressed in terms of the equivalent strain εeq. Since the functions E2 o=E2 o(ɛeq) and G12 o=G12 o(ɛeq) are only known at points, and not as a mathematical function, spline-interpolations of these curves were implemented for the range of experimental data (in a stand-alone program for the unidirectional test cases and in a finite element program for the laminate test cases). Because the composite can withstand for specific load combinations higher strains than those verified by uniaxial testing, an extrapolation of the experimental data is also necessary. The extrapolations of the curves for the five material systems used in the exercise are shown in Figure 4. It should be noted that the extrapolation is subjective, particularly on what concerns the inflection points visible in Figure 4. Ideally, the extrapolation ought to be guided by suitable multi-axial data for each material system. Figure 4.
Extrapolation of the experimental longitudinal shear and transverse compression curves.

sec.title: Unloading
sec.p: The test cases proposed by the present exercise do not require the capability to model unloading. However, material healing during unloading can be prevented by simply defining the history field variable κ at time t as (8)κ(t)=maxt *≤t{ɛeq(t *)} and the Young’s and shear moduli for no superposed hydrostatic pressure E2 o and G12 o are defined as function of the maximum equivalent strain in the loading history, (9)E2 o=E2 o(κ)G12 o=G12 o(κ), instead of being calculated by equation (7).

sec.title: Failure model at the ply level
Failure of polymers
sec.p:
Strength of polymers is greatly affected by the hydrostatic pressure. Experimental data shows that the failure stress increases linearly with pressure until a given pressure, after which the growth rate appears to decrease,12,27,28 see Figure 5. Figure 5.
Experimental failure points for an epoxy resin, after reference [22], and predictions using Raghava and modified von Mises criteria.

Physically, the increase in strength with pressure12,27,28 can be attributed to two separate factors. Firstly, the compressive stresses close micro-crack tips thus allowing for both friction and mechanical locking between the faces of the microcracks, resulting in a strengthening effect. Secondly, the volumetric deformation induced by the hydrostatic pressure increases the entanglement of the polymer chains, which might further restrict crack growth.

Experimental data can be predicted with good accuracy using different pressure-dependent criteria, such as the Mohr-Coulomb, modified Tresca, modified von Mises, Raghava,29 Li-Wu30 and Altenbach-Tushev28 criteria. Some of these are summarised in Table 2. The criterion proposed by the authors for the failure exercise is the Raghava29 criterion: (10)FIp=3(k2-(T-C)σh)TC, where T is the tensile strength of the resin, C is the compressive strength of the resin, σh is the hydrostatic stress defined as (11)3σh=σx+σy+σz and k is defined as (12)6k2=(σP1-σP2)2+(σP2-σP3)2+(σP3-σP1)2, with σPi being the principal stresses. The Raghava criterion is chosen because it is able to capture the change in slope verified experimentally at high pressures, while still remaining relatively simple. Table 2.
Failure criteria for polymers
Criterion Equationa
Mohr-Coulomb τfp=S-ησn
Modified Tresca τmax=S-ησh
Modified von Mises k=ko-ησh
Raghava [29] k2=(T-C)σh+TC/3
a
τfp is the shear stress acting on a potential fracture plane; σn is the normal traction acting on a potential fracture plane; τmax is the maximum shear stress; ko and η are parameters which depend on the criterion and can be calculated from uniaxial test data; S is the shear strength and k is defined in equation (12).

sec.title: In-situ effects
sec.p: The strengths associated with matrix-dominated failure in a composite should not be expected to be material properties. They are structural properties, dependent on the thickness of the ply, and on the neighbouring plies in the laminate. Under the same stress state (averaged over ply thickness), the conditions for the propagation of micro-cracks are much more favourable for the case of a UD laminate than for a thin ply in a multi-axial laminate neighboured by 0° plies. The thickness of the ply and the presence of neighbouring plies change the boundary conditions of the fracture mechanics problem for crack growth. This observation is at the root of the in-situ effects on the strength presented in this section.

Consider the different types of plies presented in Figure 6, which include an equivalent slit crack. The equivalent slit crack is an equivalent crack of a well-defined shape and orientation which purposes to represent the existing microcracks in the ply, resulting from manufacturing. The conditions for crack propagation can be related to the longitudinal and transverse critical energy release rates for mode I and mode II by (see also References [2,6,31,32]): (13)GIc=Yπaom4ξ2(YT is)GIIc L=YπaomξL(SL is)GIIc T=YπaomξT(ST is) where GIc, GIIc L and GIIc T are the mode I and mode II (longitudinal and transverse) fracture toughness, respectively, Y is a geometry-dependent factor, m is equal to either 2, for unstable propagation in the transverse direction, or 4, for unstable propagation in the longitudinal direction. The strengths YT is, SL is and ST is are the in-situ transverse tensile strength, longitudinal shear strength and transverse shear strengths, respectively. These strengths are in-situ because they depend on the thickness of the ply and on the location of the ply in the laminate (inner or outer ply). The functions ξ(σ) represent the area under the strain versus stress curve up to the point (ɛ,σ), and are thus defined as (14)ξ2(σ)=∫0 ɛ(σ)σ2dɛ2ξL(τ)=∫0 γ(τ)τLdγLξT(τ)=∫0 γ(τ)τTdγT. Figure 6.
Slit crack considered for in-situ effects. (a) Ply in a UD laminate; (b) thin outer ply; (c) thin embedded ply and (d) thick embedded ply.

The function ξ2(σ) is obtained from a standard transverse tensile test. The function ξL(τ) is obtained from a longitudinal shear test and the function ξT(τ) is obtained from a transverse compressive test. However, the functions are not derived directly from the tests but rather from the spline curves with inter- and extrapolation shown in Figure 4. The variables τL and τT are the longitudinal and transverse shear stresses (see Figure 7), and their significance is discussed in the next section. The fracture mechanics solutions for the four types of plies are summarised in Table 3 (see also References [1,2,6]). Figure 7.
Traction components acting on the matrix fracture plane, from reference [2]. Table 3.
Formulae for in-situ strengthsa

sec.title: Matrix failure criterion
sec.p: Matrix-dominated failure in composites has similarities to that of pure polymer. This would indicate that criteria analogous to Raghava’s29 would be amongst the most suitable to predict matrix failure in a composite. However, to predict the consequences of failure in composites knowing the fracture angle becomes extremely important. Variations of the Mohr-Coulomb criterion, first proposed for composites by Puck and co-workers,33–37 have proven to be capable of predicting matrix failure under multi-axial stress states and have the added advantage that the fracture angle comes directly with the prediction. For these reasons, the criterion proposed here for matrix failure is an adaptation of the Mohr-Coulomb failure criterion for UD composite plies. The failure index for matrix failure is defined as: (15)FIM=(τTST is-ηTσN)2+(τLSL is-ηLσN)2+(áσNñ+YT is)2, with failure being predicted when FIM≥1. The last term in the criterion represents the contribution from the positive normal traction in opening the cracks. Therefore, this criterion is intended to be applicable for both tensile and compressive matrix failure.

In equation (15), τL, τT and σN are the traction components in the (potential) fracture plane, see Figure 7, and are obtained by stress transformation: (16)σN=σ2+σ32+σ2-σ32cos(2α)+τ23sin(2α)τT=-σ2-σ32sin(2α)+τ23cos(2α)τL=τ12cos(α)+τ31sin(α) where α is the angle that maximizes FIM and is obtained numerically by evaluating the function at selected angles in the interval 0∘≤α<180∘ as per References [2,5,38]. The particular value of α for pure transverse compression, αo, is a material property that can be measured experimentally. Several sources have observed that the fracture angle for either glass or carbon composites is typically 51∘≤αo≤55∘.2,4,36

The slope or friction coefficients ηT and ηL in equation (15) are introduced to account for the effect of pressure on the failure response. Their effect is that of increasing the respective shear strengths in the presence of a compressive normal traction and reducing the respective shear strengths in the presence of a tensile normal traction. The slope or friction coefficient ηT is obtained from the pure transverse compression test as a function of αo,2 (17)ηT=-1tan(2αo), while the slope or friction coefficient ηL is an independent material property that needs to be measured experimentally, see Table 1. Finally, the McCauley brackets á•ñ+ in equation (15) are defined as áxñ+=max{0,x}.

sec.title: Fibre kinking failure
sec.p: The physics of axial compressive failure are arguably less understood than for any other failure mode in composites. The experimental fact is that kink bands are observed in the material after failure. Although similar kink bands appear in different materials and at different scales, the reasons for their formation, at least for polymer-matrix fibre-reinforced composites, seems far from agreed upon by all researchers in the area. While a stream of researchers follows the hypothesis from Rosen39 according to which kink band failure is somehow the final result of the microbuckling of the fibres, another stream follows Argon40 and argues that kink bands are triggered by localised matrix failure next to misaligned fibres.41,42 Both streams have in common that they do not predict directly how kink bands form but rather predict an event (microbuckling or matrix failure) which triggers the formation of kink bands.

The micrographs in Figure 8 show different stages of kink-band formation in a T300/913 specimen. Matrix splitting in between the fibres can be identified in Figure 8(b) and is the result of the high shear stresses introduced by failure in the neighbouring plies. In general, the high localised shear stresses can also be introduced by manufacturing defects, such as fibre misalignments. The splitting promotes further bending of the fibres, which in turn results in more splitting, Figure 8(c). The bent fibres eventually break due to the combination of bending and compressive stresses, first at one end and then at the other, finally resulting in a kink band, Figure 8(d). Experimental observations, as shown in Figure 8, suggest that kink bands are preceded by matrix failure and that microbuckling is not necessarily the triggering factor for failure. Figure 8.
Sequence of events during kink-band formation. The laminate is being loaded in compression in the vertical direction. (a) Misalignment introduced by a matrix crack in an adjacent layer. (b) Matrix-fibre splitting exists throughout (see zoom); the first fibre failures are indicated. (c) Further fibre failure. (d) Final kink band. Legend.  ( Matrix cracking; ‚ Fibre failure.

Following the previous observations, fibre kinking is assumed to result from shear-dominated matrix failure in a misaligned frame, under significant longitudinal compression. However, if the longitudinal compression is not significant, the shear-dominated matrix failure on the misaligned frame results in fibre splitting but not necessarily in fibre kinking. Experimental data for combined longitudinal compression and inplane shear for a carbon/epoxy T300/LY556-HY917-DY07043 suggests that fibre kinking only takes place for an absolute value of longitudinal compression greater than XC/2. However, for longitudinal compression combined with transverse tension, experimental results for T800/92444 indicate that no kink bands are formed if the magnitude of the longitudinal compression is lower than XC.
The criteria proposed here for fibre kinking and for splitting use the same failure index equation written as (18)FIKINK=FISPLIT=(τ23 mST is-ηTσ2 m)2+(τ12 mSL is-ηLσ2 m)2 +(áσ2 mñ+YT is)2.

The two failure modes are then distinguished based on the magnitude of longitudinal compression with σ1≤-XC/2 indicating fibre kinking and σ1≥-XC/2 signifying fibre splitting. This distinction is relevant for the propagation of failure.

The rotated coordinate systems relevant for the description of a kink band are shown in Figure 9. The relevant stress rotation equations are for rotation to the kink-band plane ψ: (19)σ1≥-XC/2 and for the subsequent rotation to the misalignment frame: (20) {σ2 m=sin2ϕσ1+cos2ϕσ2 ψ-2sinϕcosϕτ12 ψτ12 m=-sinϕcosϕσ1+sinϕcosϕσ2 ψ+(cos2ϕ-sin2ϕ)τ12 ψτ23 m=τ23 ψcosϕ-τ31 ψsinϕ Figure 9.
Physical model for kink-band formation.

The angle of the kink band, ψ, is found numerically in the range 0∘≤ψ<180∘ so as to maximise the failure index (FI) in equation (18). The misalignment angle, φ, is the sum of the initial misalignment angle φo (manufacturing defect) and the shear strain γmo expressed in a coordinate system aligned with the manufacturing defect: (21)ϕ=sign(τ12 ψ)ϕo+γmo.
The strain γmo is a function of the corresponding shear stress, τmo, as (22)γmo=γ(τmo).

The initial misalignment angle φo is a material property which can be obtained from the longitudinal compressive strength solving the following iterative equation: (23)ϕo=ϕc-γ(12sin(2ϕo)XC), where ϕc is given by Reference [2] (24)ϕc=arctan(1-1-4(SLXC+ηL)SLXC2(SLXC+ηL)).

sec.title: Fibre tensile failure
sec.p: The maximum stress failure criterion has been shown to correlate well with existing experimental data45 regarding fibre tensile failure. Therefore, the maximum stress criterion here is used to predict this failure mode: (25)FIFT=áσ1ñ+XT.

sec.title: Propagation of failure
sec.p: When any of the failure indices reaches 1, the constitutive law is modified to simulate the formation and propagation of cracks/damage in the composite. Propagation of failure is processed differently for different failure modes, taking into account their specificities, but following a common approach. More specifically, the components of the traction acting on the predicted fracture plane are reduced to zero. The reduction of tractions is performed in such a way that the energy dissipation predicted by the numerical model per unit area of created surface equals the fracture toughness of the material for the respective failure mode. The stresses obtained from Hooke’s law are designated effective stresses, as they are the stresses that act on the effective resisting area of the material once failure started propagating. The stresses which are in fact applied to the material, dependent on damage, are designated nominal stresses.

The effective stress tensor in the material coordinate system σ¯123 is rotated to a coordinate system aligned with the fracture plane, as shown in Figure 10, thus defining σ¯ℓmn={σℓσmσnτℓmτmnτnℓ}T. The effective traction vector is given as t¯={σnτmnτnℓ}T. The presence of the crack/damage is simulated by degrading the traction components, such that the nominal tractions are defined as (26)t={(1-dáσnñ+σn)σn(1-d)τmn(1-d)τnℓ}T. Figure 10.
Coordinate system aligned with the crack.

The McCauley brackets in the first term indicate that the normal component of the traction is degraded in tension but not in compression. The nominal stresses expressed in the coordinate system aligned with the fracture plane are (27)σℓmn={σℓσm(1-dáσnñ+σn)σnτℓm(1-d)τmn(1-d)τnℓ}T.
This nominal stress vector is then rotated back to the material axes.

The evolution of the damage variable d defines how much energy is dissipated by damage. To assess this energy, the non-elastic component of the strain due to yielding is first removed from the total strain. The elastic strain, in the material coordinate system, is given by the expression (28)ɛ123 el=Del-1σ¯123, where Del is similar to D defined in Equation 3, but using the initial moduli instead of the moduli affect by yielding. In other words, Del does not include the effect of yielding on the moduli but does include the effect of hydrostatic pressure.

If only traction vector components are degraded, the dissipated energy can be computed from the internal product of the elastic strain vector on the fracture plane, {ɛn elγmn elγnl el}T, and the traction vector, t. This is equivalent to projecting the elastic fracture plane strain vector onto the direction of the traction vector and multiplying the magnitude of the projected vector, designated here as εel, with the magnitude of the nominal traction vector, σ. From that it is clear that σ and εel are work-conjugate, and the energy per unit volume dissipated by failure can be visualized by the area under the (ɛel,σ) curve. The damage variable d is finally defined for each failure mode as a function of εel and the magnitude of the effective traction vector, σ¯, in such a way that the energy absorbed by failure equals the fracture toughness for the respective failure mode as outlined in the following sections.
The damage propagation model presented here includes three independent damage variables: one for matrix failure, one for fibre kinking and one for fibre tensile failure.

sec.title: Matrix failure
sec.p:
The mechanical response of a composite ply during matrix failure propagation depends on the angle of fracture α and on the type of ply (ply in a UD specimen, embedded ply, or outer ply). For a multidirectional laminate, two different situations can be distinguished regarding the fracture angle α. If the angle is equal to zero, then the formation of the first crack is followed by the formation of further cracks, until a saturation level is reached at which delamination occurs, see Figure 11. This saturation level can be determined experimentally or obtained using a shear lag model.46 If the angle α is not zero, as it is typically the case in compression, then a wedge effect will trigger delamination after the first crack is created, see Figure 12. Figure 11.
Progressive cracking for an angle α = 0. Figure 12.
Wedge effect for an angle α ≠ 0.

sec.title: Multidirectional laminates with fracture angle α=0
Embedded ply
sec.p:
In a multidirectional laminate, after the formation of the first matrix crack with α equal to zero, stresses can still be transmitted to the failed ply by shear from the neighbouring plies. Because of this, the effect of a crack on the stress field will vanish at relatively small distances from this crack and further cracks will be formed. During this period of crack accumulation, it is here assumed that the nominal stress remains constant with increased strain. Eventually, the number of cracks will saturate as the distance between neighbouring cracks becomes too small to transmit stresses to the layer. The saturation crack density, n, can be calculated from a shear lag model by assuming constant shear stresses at the interface equal to the shear strength (see Figure 13), as (29)n=SL ishYT is, where h is the total thickness of the plies with the same orientation clustered together. The energy per unit volume dissipated by the formation of these cracks is Ucrack=0.5σo(ɛd-ɛo), as indicated by the shaded triangle on the left in Figure 11. On the other hand, the total energy required for the formation of the new cracks in an element of volume V is nVGc, where Gc is the critical energy release rate for the failure mode. Therefore, the strain εd at the onset of delamination (see Figure 11) can be determined as (30)ɛd=ɛo+2nGcσo, where σo is the magnitude of the traction at the onset of failure. When the strain εd is reached, further loading will result in delamination, as shown in Figure 11. The energy per unit volume dissipated by the model is Udelam=0.5σoɛf, as indicated by the shaded triangle in the right in Figure 11. However, the energy dissipated by delamination should be the area of delamination multiplied by the mode II interlaminar critical energy release rate GIIc, which results in the following expression for εf: (31)ɛf=2GIIcσot, where t is the thickness of the element. Figure 13.
Shear lag model.

To reproduce the shape of the stress vs. strain response in Figure 11, the damage variable d for matrix failure in embedded plies with α equal to zero is then defined as the maximum value in time of (32)dinst=max{0,min{1-σoσ¯,1-σoσ¯ɛf-ɛelɛf-ɛd,1}},d=maxtime{dinst}

sec.title: Outer ply
sec.p: For the purpose of accumulation of matrix cracks, outer plies differ from embedded plies because shear from neighbouring plies are only transmitted from one side of the ply. Applying a shear lag model for outer plies results in a crack saturation density half of that for embedded plies: (33)n=SL is2hYT is.
Damage propagation for outer plies is processed in the same way as for embedded plies, but with the saturation density given by equation (33).

sec.title: Multidirectional laminates with fracture angle α≠0
sec.p: If a matrix crack is formed in a multidirectional laminate with α different from zero, a wedge effect will promote delamination. The traction vs. strain curve for this damage mode is assumed to be bilinear, as shown in Figure 12. The energy per unit volume dissipated by the model is 0.5σoɛf while the energy dissipated by the crack is the area of fracture multiplied by the critical energy release rate for that failure mode. This results in the following expression for εf: (34)ɛf=2Gc/GcL L+GIc/GIct tσo.

In equation (34), L is a characteristic length related to the mesh size (ratio of the volume of the element to the area of the fracture surface) and is calculated using the algorithm detailed in Reference [3]. Gc is calculated using the power law according to Reference [3].

To reproduce the shape of the stress vs. strain response in Figure 12, the damage variable d for matrix failure in multidirectional laminates with fracture angle α different from zero is then defined as the maximum value in time of (35)dinst=max{0,min{1-σoσ¯ɛf-ɛelɛf-ɛo,1}},d=maxtime{dinst}.

sec.title: UD laminates
sec.p: For UD laminates, there is no accumulation of cracks regardless of the fracture angle α and a bilinear curve is assumed. Equating the energy dissipated by the element (0.5σoɛfV) to the energy dissipated by fracture (GcA), the following expression for εf is obtained: (36)ɛf=2Gc/GcL Lσo.
The damage variable d is defined by equation (35).

sec.title: Fibre kinking
sec.p: In this work, kink bands are simulated as localised bands of failed material similar to fracture planes. A bilinear law is used to degrade the traction components acting on the equivalent fracture plane. For the definition of the bilinear law, εf is given by equation (36) (with Gc in this case being equal to the critical energy release rate for fibre kinking) and the damage variable d is defined by equation (35).

sec.title: Fibre tensile failure
sec.p: Fibre tensile fracture planes are assumed to be normal to the fibre direction. It is worth noticing that recent results47,48 indicate that a softening relation defined by two softening curves might be required to accurately represent the different energy dissipation mechanisms associated with longitudinal fracture. Using more than one softening law requires the identification of the transition strength as well as the partition of the fracture energy. These material properties are not available for the material used here. Therefore, a bilinear law is also used for this failure mode, where εf is given by equation (36) (using the critical energy release rate for fibre tensile failure for Gc) and the damage variable d is defined by equation (35).

sec.title: Yielding of the resin
sec.p: As pointed out in Section 0, specimens used for characterising the composite lamina include little information on the yielding response of the resin, and the corresponding nonlinear curves have to be extrapolated. The implications of this extrapolation can be very significant for loading cases with considerable yielding.

sec.title: Effect of hydrostatic pressure
sec.p: The slope coefficients for the elastic properties and shear strengths (longitudinal and transverse) of a ply are intrinsic material properties. In this exercise, they have to be assumed (note that although ηT was calculated from αo, the latter was assumed), but they should ideally be measured experimentally for each material system.

sec.title: Residual thermal stresses
sec.p: Thermal stresses can potentially have a significant effect on the failure mode and failure load of a laminate. For the predictions contained in this paper, it is assumed that the laminates were stress-free at the cure temperature and that testing occurred at 20°C, without any relaxation of stresses having taken place.

sec.title: Edge effects
sec.p: Delamination and edge effects may trigger failure of a laminate. The failure stresses become therefore structural properties, and their prediction requires knowing the geometry of the specimen tested. Without this knowledge, edge effects cannot realistically be accounted for, compromising any predictions made for multidirectional laminates. Following the guidelines from the organisers of the WWFE-II,49 edge effects are not taken into account in this part of the exercise, which might result in an inappropriate representation of the specimens actually tested.

sec.title: In-situ effects
sec.p: For the matrix-dominated failure modes, the strength of a ply depends on its thickness and on the existence and orientation of the neighbouring plies. For this reason, it is essential for strength predictions of multidirectional laminates to know the thickness of each individual ply, as well as the exact stacking sequence. For this exercise, the thickness of each ply is not given and neither is the exact stacking sequence. A less accurate estimation of the in-situ strengths can result in the predicted failure envelopes being offset with respect to the experimental ones.

sec.title: Statistical effects
sec.p: The mechanical properties of a composite – both elastic and strength – vary from point to point in a specimen. There is therefore an intrinsic limitation in predicting the deterministic strength of a laminate based on the deterministic strength of the plies. Ideally, the distribution of the probability of failure of a laminate could be obtained provided the distribution of ply properties and geometry and size of the specimen are known. Since the distribution of ply properties is not known, and neither are the size of the specimens, statistical effects cannot be taken into account.

sec.title: Fracture toughness
sec.p: The in-situ strengths for the matrix-dominated failure modes depend on the matrix intralaminar fracture toughnesses and the progressive failure of a laminate depends on the fracture toughness for each failure mode taking place. Because the fracture toughnesses for each failure mode are not known, notably for the fibre-dominated failure modes, typical values obtained from literature and from the authors’ experience are used. However, there is in some cases little data available and a better knowledge of the values of these properties could improve the predictions.

sec.title: Manufacturing method
sec.p: Many mechanical properties of a composite are considerably dependent on the manufacturing method. For instance, the strength associated with fibre kinking depends greatly on existing defects such as fibre misalignments, non-uniform fibre distribution, micro-cracks, voids, etc. The strengths associated with the matrix-dominated failure modes, particularly in tension, are also greatly affected by defects such as microcracks and voids. Therefore, if the manufacturing method used to manufacture the specimens for the test cases is not the same as the manufacturing method used for the material characterisation, the ply strengths might not be entirely representative of the laminate’s strengths. For this reason, it is important to guarantee that, to the extent possible, all specimens are manufactured using the same method.

sec.title: Application of accurate boundary conditions
sec.p: For the test cases involving laminates under 3D stress states (test cases 8 to 12), the correct representation of the boundary conditions and the stress state in the laminate is here achieved using an implementation of the failure model described in a finite element code. For each test case, laminates with 16 plies, each 0.25 mm thick, are modelled, and appropriate boundary conditions are applied to the models.

sec.title: Predictions
sec.p:
The test cases for WWFE-II are summarised in Table 4 and full details of the lay-ups, materials and loading conditions are provided in Reference [49]. The material properties used for the predictions are summarised in Table 5. The predictions for test cases 1 to 12 are presented in Figure 14 to Figure 25, respectively. Figure 14.
Predicted envelope for test case 1 – shear failure of MY750 epoxy resin under superimposed hydrostatic pressure. Table 4.
Details of the 12 test cases used in WWFE-II49
Test Case Laminate lay-up Material Description of Required Prediction
1 Resin MY750 epoxy σx versus σz (with σy = σz) envelope
2 0° T300/PR319 τ12 versus σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3) envelope
3 0° T300/PR319 γ12 versus σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3) envelope
4 0° T300/PR319 Shear stress strain curves (τ12 − γ12) (for σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = −600 MPa)
5 90° E-glass/MY750 epoxy σ2 versus σ3 (with σ1 = σ3) envelope
6 0° S-glass/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 (with σ2 = σ3) envelope
7 0° A-S carbon/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 (with σ2 = σ3) envelope
8 ±35° E-glass/MY750 epoxy σy versus σz (with σx = σz) envelope
9 ±35° E-glass/MY750 epoxy Stress-strain curves (σy −εx and σy −εy) at σz = σx = −100 MPa
10 (0°/90°/±45°)s IM7/8551-7 τyz versus σz (with σy = σx = 0) envelope
11 (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 τyz versus σz (with σy = σx = 0) envelope
12 (0°/90°)s IM7/8551-7 Stress-strain curves (σz − εz, σz − εx and σz − εy) for σy = σx = 0
Table 5.

For the test cases corresponding to UD plies, the predictions were carried out using a simple explicit implementation of the constitutive response using a stand-alone Fortran code. For the test cases corresponding to multidirectional laminates, a 3D explicit finite element implementation was used to calculate the ply stresses, since these cannot be obtained from classical lamination theory. For each of the test cases 8 to 12, a simple model of the laminate was created with suitable boundary conditions so that the ply stresses would be calculated from laminate stresses by the FE code. Being explicit, the implementations only require secant stiffnesses to be computed, and all material nonlinearities measured at the ply level could be included. The explicit implementation avoids the convergence problems typical of implicit implementations.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This section is divided in the test case for resin (test case 1), the test cases for UD laminates (test cases 2 to 7) and the test cases for multidirectional laminates (test cases 8 to 12). The test case for pure resin is naturally different since it does not correspond to the failure of a composite. The division between UD and multidirectional laminates arises because prediction of the strength for the latter requires considering in-situ effects, residual thermal stresses and propagation of failure, while prediction of strength for the former does not. As mentioned above, the predictions for UD plies were carried out with a stand-alone explicit implementation of the model, while the predictions for multidirectional laminates were carried out with an explicit finite element implementation.

sec.title: Pure resin
sec.p: Failure of pure resin appears to be fairly well understood, and several publications in the literature succeed in predicting failure of pure resin accurately. The pressure-dependent strength of pure resin is approximately linear, at least for low superimposed hydrostatic pressures, and needs to be characterised experimentally. The proposed prediction for test case 1 is shown in Figure 14. It can be seen that using the Raghava criterion leads to a slightly nonlinear influence of hydrostatic pressure on strength and that it predicts no failure for pure hydrostatic compression.

sec.title: Test case 2
sec.p:
In test case 2, the τ12 vs. σ2 failure envelope with σ1=σ2=σ3 for T300/PR319 is requested. Figure 15 shows that the predicted envelope is open for σ2<0, and the composite is thus not expected to fail under hydrostatic compression. The failure model (equation (15)) predicts for this case a constant slope of the τ12 vs. σ2 failure envelope for σ2<0. The magnitude of the slope of the envelope is defined by the material property ηL, which is not provided for this exercise. Nevertheless, any deviation from linearity of the experimental data would indicate a limitation of the current model. Figure 15.
Predicted envelope for test case 2 – τ12 vs. σ2 failure envelope with σ1=σ2=σ3 for T300/PR319.

Coincidentally, this loading condition and material has been studied by Shin and Pae.3,11,12 They tested composite tubes under torsion and hydrostatic pressure, with fibres at 0° and at 90° to the axial direction. The experimental results are also shown in Figure 15. The in-plane shear strength is different for the 0° and 90° specimens, although it could be expected that it should be one single property. It is likely that the different manufacturing required by the different stacking sequences results in different initial defects in the material. Furthermore, the rotation of the fibres during loading is different for the different specimens. Both these factors are responsible for the different strengths measured. Another aspect worth mentioning is that, for moderate compression, the slope for both types of specimens appears to be the same. This coincidence might be because the compression closes any previously existing micro-cracks (and therefore the slope is less sensitive to the magnitude of manufacturing imperfections) and the nonlinear geometric effects are not yet very significant. For higher compressive loads, the strength and thus strain to failure increases, and the geometric effects are therefore more significant. Geometric effects might explain why the strengths for 0°and 90° specimens becomes different again. The different response of specimens that are conceptually identical illustrates well the problem of predicting failure in composites.

Because the specimens with fibres at 90° should not suffer fibre rotation during the application of shear, the parameter ηL used in the predictions was obtained by best fitting the corresponding experimental data. Therefore, while the linear dependence of the shear strength on the hydrostatic pressure is a characteristic of the model, the good agreement with the experimental data presented is also due to the fact that ηL was obtained from the same data set.

sec.title: Test case 3
sec.p:
Shin and Pae11,12 also measured the strain to failure for the T300/PR319 specimens mentioned previously, allowing for a γ12 vs. σ2 envelope to be drawn, as shown in Figure 16. This figure also shows the predictions of the current model, requested for test case 3. It can be seen that the model predicts an almost linear dependence of the shear strain to failure on σ2. No experimental failure strain-related information from Shin and Pae11,12 was used for the case of this envelope, and any agreement between experimental and numerical results is fully predictive. Given a prediction for the strength of the specimen, the aspects of the model that determine the predicted strain to failure are those related to the nonlinear response and include the pressure-dependence of G12 (equation (4)), the definition of the equivalent strain used (equation (6)) and the necessary extrapolation of the experimental shear stress vs. strain curve (Figure 4). Figure 16.
Predicted envelope for test case 3 – γ12 vs. σ2 failure envelope with σ1=σ2=σ3 for T300/PR319.

sec.title: Test case 4
sec.p:
The curve τ12 vs. γ12 for σ1=σ2=σ3=-600MPa is requested in test case 4 for the same material T300/PR319 which was also measured by Shin and Pae,11,12 see Figure 17. This figure also shows the predictions from the current model. As for the previous test case, the experimental curve from Shin and Pae11,12 is not used in any way for the predictions, and any agreement between experimental and numerical is fully predictive. The aspects of the model that are relevant for this prediction are the strength prediction (equation (15)) and the nonlinear aspects of the model as explained in the discussion of test case 3. Figure 17.
Predicted stress vs. strain response for test case 4 – τ12 vs. γ12 with σ1=σ2=σ3=-600MPa for T300/PR319.

sec.title: Test case 5
sec.p:
Test case 5 requests the σ2 vs. σ3 failure envelope for E-glass/MY750 epoxy with σ1=σ3. The predictions, shown in Figure 18, indicate that the envelope is open under pure hydrostatic pressure. The segments adjacent to the open part of the envelope are linear. The lack of interaction between σ2 and σ3 for positive values of both stress components is an interesting feature of the predicted envelope. The failure envelope is symmetrical about the pure hydrostatic pressure line. For the load combinations in test case 5, the failure mode is always matrix failure. In particular, fibre kinking is never predicted as the first failure mode to occur. However, it should be noted that, for matrix failure under considerable superposed hydrostatic pressure, the stress state in the specimen after matrix failure can in principle lead to subsequent fibre kinking, depending on the specimen and on how the load is applied. The angle of matrix failure changes from α=0∘ to α=53∘, the latter being an input value (αo). In the first quadrant, the change in angle α=90∘ to α=0∘ occurs at a stress ratio σ2/σ3=1. In the second quadrant, the change in angle α=53∘ to α=90∘ occurs for stress ratios σ2/σ3 in the approximate range [-2.75,-1.73]. In the fourth quadrant, the change in angle α=37∘ to α=0∘ occurs for stress ratios σ2/σ3 in the approximate range [-0.58,-0.36]. Figure 18.
Predicted envelope for test case 5 – σ2 vs. σ3 failure envelope for E-glass/MY750 epoxy with σ1=σ3.

sec.title: Test case 6
sec.p:
The σ1 vs. σ3 failure envelope for S-glass/epoxy with σ2=σ3 is requested for test case 6. The predicted failure envelope, shown in Figure 19, is again open for pure hydrostatic pressure. On the left part of the envelope, it can be seen that an increase in fibre-kinking strength is predicted with hydrostatic pressure. The exact (non-constant) slope of the envelope in this region results from the combination of many features of the model, including nonlinear response, slope coefficients on the elastic properties and shear strengths, definition of equivalent strain, and extrapolation of the nonlinear stress vs. strain curves. Figure 19.
Predicted envelope for test case 6 – σ1 vs. σ3 failure envelope for S-glass/epoxy with σ2=σ3.

sec.title: Test case 7
sec.p:
Test case 7 is the same as test case 6, but for A-S carbon/epoxy instead of S-glass/epoxy. The predictions, shown in Figure 20, are qualitatively similar, and the same discussion as for test case 6 applies, since the proposed model does not distinguish between carbon and glass fibre composites. Although glass fibres tend to exhibit some nonlinear response, this effect is not considered to be significant and is not taken into account. Figure 20.
Predicted envelope for test case 7 – σ1 vs. σ3 failure envelope with σ2=σ3 for A-S carbon/epoxy.

sec.title: Multidirectional laminates
sec.p: In the present model, the strength for the matrix-dominated failure modes depends on the thickness of the plies in the laminate, which is here assumed to be 0.25 mm. Furthermore, their accurate evaluation requires assuming the values of the respective fracture energies and the extrapolation of experimental nonlinear constitutive curves. Finally, the effect of weaker outer plies on the final failure of the laminate depends on the number of plies, which is here unless otherwise stated assumed to be 16. As a result, there is considerable scope for the properties used and laminate simulated not corresponding exactly to the experimental tests; consequently, some deviation might be expected regarding quantitative predictions. Qualitative results such as the shape of failure envelopes and predicted failure modes are expected to provide a validation of the general model assumptions.

sec.title: Test case 8
sec.p:
Test case 8 requires the σy vs. σz (with σx=σz) envelope for a ±35° laminate of E-glass/MY750 epoxy, as shown in Figure 21. It can be observed that the envelope is open for pure hydrostatic pressure. Depending on the load combination, the specimen can fail by matrix cracking, fibre splitting or fibre kinking. The matrix fracture angle within each individual ply, α=45∘, is interesting, as it has not appeared in previous envelopes; it is the result of shear-dominated matrix failure, with some transverse compression. Notice that, due to the multidirectional nature of the laminate, the macroscopic fracture angle of the laminate is not 45°. However, the 45° fracture on each ply should be observable using microscopy. Figure 21.
Predicted envelope for test case 8 – σy vs. σz (with σx=σz) envelope for a ±35° laminate of E-glass/MY750 epoxy.

sec.title: Test case 9
sec.p:
The stress vs. strain curves for compression in y-direction, σy vs. εx and σy vs. εy at σz=σx=-100MPa are requested in test case 9 for the same laminate as in test case 8, see Figure 22. The pronounced nonlinearity for high strains can be observed very clearly. This nonlinearity results from the nonlinear matrix response, and hence depends on the extrapolation of the constitutive response (Figure 4). Two curves are shown in Figure 22; one corresponding to an 8-ply model and another corresponding to a 50-ply model. The initiation of failure is predicted in both cases for the same stress at the outer plies. However, the effect of the failure of the outer plies in the subsequent response of the laminate can be observed to be more pronounced for the model with 8 plies only. Both models predict a matrix fracture angle within each individual ply α=45∘. Figure 22.
Predicted stress vs. strain response for test case 9 – σy vs. εx and σy vs. εy at σz=σx=-100MPa for a ±35° laminate of E-glass/MY750 epoxy.

sec.title: Test case 10
sec.p:
Test case 10 requests the τyz vs. σz envelope for a (0°/90°/±45°)s laminate of IM7/8551-7. The specimen fails by matrix failure in the outer ply for all load combinations, without clear separation between initial and final failure, see Figure 23. Moderate through-the-thickness compression is seen to improve the strength of the laminate. The ply to fail first is the outer ply, which restricts how further load can be applied to the specimen, given the z component of the loading. The fracture angles range from 30° to 90°, as indicated in Figure 23. Figure 23.
Predicted envelope for test case 10 – τyz vs. σz envelope for a (0°/90°/±45°)s laminate of IM7/8551-7.

sec.title: Test case 11
sec.p:
Test case 11 is the same as test case 10, but for a (0°/90°)s laminate. The results, presented in Figure 24, are qualitatively similar to test case 10. Figure 24.
Predicted envelope for test case 11 – τyz vs. σz envelope for a (0°/90°)s laminate of IM7/8551-7. Figure 25.
Predicted stress vs. strain response for test case 12 – σz vs. εz and σz vs. ɛx=ɛy for a (0°/90°)s laminate of IM7/8551-7.

sec.title: Test case 12
sec.p: The stress–strain curves σz vs. εz and σz vs. ɛx=ɛy for the same laminate as the one in test case 11 are requested in test case 12. The nonlinearity that can be observed in Figure 25, in particular the stiffening at a stress of about 200 MPa, depends largely on the extrapolation of the constitutive shear curves. More evolved processes for extrapolating the constitutive curves for cases which exhibit more plasticity than in the tests used to measure material properties ought to be investigated in the future.
The predictions from this model are compared with those involved in the WWFE-II in Reference [50].

list-item.p: The mechanical response of fibre-reinforced laminated composites is nonlinear and pressure-dependent. At the microscopic scale, different mechanisms such as deformation of polymer chains and breakage of cross-links, crazing or void formation and propagation of micro-cracks compete for damage and failure of the matrix. For fibre kinking, the respective micromechanics are not yet clearly understood.

At a mesoscopic scale (ply level), the presence of neighbouring plies influences the propagation of microcracks, thus resulting in an in-situ strength which is different from the strength measured on a unidirectional specimen.

The understanding of all of these phenomena is not complete yet, but significant progress has been made in the past decades. The relation between complexity of a phenomenon and its relevance in terms of material response is not always easy to assess, and therefore the most appropriate compromise between complexity of a model and its predictive capability is not always straightforward to define.

In this paper, a nonlinear constitutive model for laminated composites which includes failure prediction is proposed. The application of the model to the test cases allows predicting not only failure itself but also the failure modes and orientation of fracture planes. The model appears to have captured interesting physical phenomena, such as open envelopes for hydrostatic compression, and the influence of hydrostatic pressure on compressive fibre failure. While it is expected that the model captures the relevant physical mechanisms and their effects appropriately, there are several issues that interfere with an accurate prediction of failure stresses and the amount of nonlinearity. First, material properties which are determinants for the initiation and propagation of failure, such as intralaminar fracture toughnesses, are not always available or readily measurable. Second, multidirectional laminates are structures on their own right, and their failure strength is determined not only by the material properties of the individual plies and generic stacking sequence but also by the total number of plies in the laminate and the number of plies clustered together.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

PP Camanho would like to acknowledge the support from the Royal Society through the International Incoming Short Visits programme. All authors would like to acknowledge Dr C Dávila’s invaluable contribution through many discussions and in proof-reading this manuscript.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
